newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan opposes U.S. "open skies" approach -- govt.
newsitem.headline: Japan opposes U.S. "open skies" approach -- govt.

text.p: A senior Japanese Transport Ministry official said on Monday that Japan is opposed to U.S. efforts to reach "open skies" accords in many aviation markets of Asia.
"This (idea of) open skies will simply invite a domination of international markets by American megacarriers," said Jiro Hanyu, deputy general of the Transport Ministry's civil aviation bureau.
Hanyu made the remarks ahead of a preparatory unofficial meeting in early January to pave the way for a resumption of negotiations, which have been deadlocked since August.
Hanyu said the U.S. is calling for "open skies" without opening the U.S. domestic market, which accounts for almost 30 percent of the world's aviation market.
"The U.S. market is dominated by four or five American carriers...and is reserved only for Americans," he said.

Mark Gerchick, deputy assistant secretary for aviation and international affairs at the U.S. Transportation Department, said earlier this month that the U.S. would put new emphasis on reaching "open skies" accords in the many closed aviation arkets of Asia.
He said Asia is the world's fastest-growing aviation market, and Japan is the key.
Hanyu called on the United States to open its domestic market to foreign carriers and to agree to a safeguard mechanism to prevent a monopoly by U.S. carriers.
He said Japan has no plans to change its stance in the bilateral aviation talks in January.

Japan argues that there is a substantial inequality over air services into the United States. "The present situation, under which Japan Airlines cannot fly to such cities as Detroit and Dallas, and All Nippon Airways cannot fly to the U.S. mainland...must be corrected," Hanyu said.

"We would like to know if the U.S. can move towards equality at the meeting. If both sides get a good impression, we will have a formal senior official level meeting very early next year, such as the end of January or in February."
The bilateral dispute centres on the granting of "beyond" rights to U.S. carriers to operate flights from the United States to Japan onward to other Asian countries.
Washington has argued that a 1952 bilateral aviation agreement allows for beyond rights for U.S. carriers but Japan says such rights have been granted only in exceptional cases.
Japan has refused to approve new flights unless the United States grants extra flights to Japanese carriers.
